title: Path traversal leading to limited CSRF on GET requests on two endpoints

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
Hi team!

I've found more endpoints which are vulnerable to the limited CSRF stated in report https://hackerone.com/reports/99708. The endpoints cause a CSRF over GET requests, however, I've been unable to exploit it.

The following endpoints are vulnerable to this:

**Proof of Concept**

1. Visit https://hackerone.com/users/confirmation?confirmation_token=z2-aaa&invitation_token=/../../test or https://hackerone.com/users/password/new?invitation_token=/../../test (the two endpoints which are still vulnerable)
1. Inspect the network traffic via developer tools or an intercepting proxy, and notice a request being made to https://hackerone.com/test.json.

We can get HackerOne to authorize Slack within a team (as attempted to do so in report 99708), however due to the state parameter it will be hard to exploit that one unless an attacker is able to get the state parameter from the victim.

## Impact

As mentioned above, it will have a big impact on HackerOne if an attacker is able to get the state parameter of the victim to, as it would lead to reports being leaked.

activities.message:
Hey.

No worries! I can wait. :)

I have just been experimenting with this, and I have noticed that passing encodeUriComponent() function to the input will prevent the use of "../../" in URLs, and thus this "vulnerability", as it encodes the input. I don't have much experience with React, so not sure what the fix was for #97708 (nor did I replicate the issue in React/find a specific fix for React),  passing encodeUriComponent() has worked for me when I replicated this issue.

summaries.content:
The issue could not be exploited directly, and therefore is a theoretical issue. It was reported after having a convo with @jobert. I'm not sure, but the request probably added a CSRF token (or equivalent) header, which made it interesting for further exploitation. For example, if there's a state-changing endpoint over GET somewhere (this would already be an issue though), which requires an additional authorization/CSRF header, this issue could become interesting. There are possibly other (better) cases where this issue could come in handy.

I hope to make it clear with this summary since the impact I described in the report is describing a totally different issue.
